children.title: abiding in Christ
children.comment: The NT stresses the need for believers to remain in Christ. The reality of this close personal relationship with Jesus Christ is expressed in obedience to his word and is essential to effective discipleship.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ tells his disciples to abide in him
NT writers exhort believers to abide in Christ
Abiding in Christ depends upon holding on to his teaching

children.title: It depends on obedience to him
It requires living like Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: Aids to abiding in Christ

children.title: Eating his flesh and drinking his blood

primaryrefs.comment: Jn 6:35-40 gives the primary explanation of this verse as being a metaphor of the believer coming in faith to Jesus Christ, ``the bread of life''. But the verse also reflects the language of the Lord's Supper.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ abides in believers

primaryrefs.comment: It is clear that the believer's ``abiding in Christ'' and Jesus Christ's ``abiding in him'' are closely connected, although the verse does not make their exact relationship clear. Because of Jesus Christ's indwelling by his Spirit, believers are able to continue to live as his disciples; as they do so, the reality of his indwelling presence is deepened.

cschildren.title: Results of abiding in Christ

primaryrefs.comment: The picture of ``bearing fruit'' may cover many aspects of Christian life but it includes that of developing Christian character, effective Christian service and mission. These result, not from human effort, but from abiding in Christ.

John is not saying that Christians are absolutely sinless. He says elsewhere that to claim sinless perfection is to deceive oneself (1Jn 1:8). But when people are born again there is the real possibility of living lives in which sin is not the norm. As believers abide in Christ more deeply, the grip of sin upon their lives is lessened.

children.title: Confidence in the face of the last day

cschildren.title: Warnings to those who fail to abide in Christ

children.title: assurance
children.comment: Certainty of a present relationship with God through Jesus Christ and a secure future hope which is based upon divine revelation, centred on the person, promises and action of God and confirmed by the Holy Spirit.

children.title: assurance, basis of
children.comment: The assurance of believers is based upon the certain knowledge of God revealed in creation and his mighty acts in history, upon the certainty of his promises, the vindication and resurrection of Christ and the inward testimony and outward demonstration of the power of the Holy Spirit.

children.title: Assurance is based upon the certain knowledge of God
Assurance comes from knowing God through creation
Assurance comes from knowing God through his mighty acts
Assurance is based upon the certainty of God's word
Assurance is based upon God's vindication of his Son
Assurance because of the resurrection of Jesus Christ
Assurance because of the miracles of Jesus Christ
Assurance comes through the work of the Holy Spirit
The Holy Spirit assures believers by enabling outward demonstrations of God's power
The Holy Spirit assures believers by giving inward conviction
The Holy Spirit assures believers by sealing God's promise
Assurance based upon the testimony of God's people
Assurance because of the testimony of eye-witnesses
Assurance because of the testimony of the apostles
Assurance is based upon godly living

seealsos.comment: love for God the Father and God the Son

children.title: assurance, nature of
children.comment: The God-given security which believers have in the blessings of divine grace. Believers are assured of the unfailing love of God and of their relationship with him as Father, the salvation and eternal life which he offers and the sure hope of one day sharing his glory.

children.title: Assurance of a relationship with God
Assurance of adoption as God's children
Assurance of confidence at Jesus Christ's return
Assurance on the day of judgment
Assurance in the hope of resurrection
Assurance in the hope of glory
Assurance in the hope of an eternal inheritance
Assurance in the hope of an eternal reward
assurance, and life of faith
children.comment: The completeness of conviction and confidence expressed in the life of the believer, worked by the Holy Spirit. It derives from a reliance upon God and his promises alone, and results in boldness and steadfastness in service and in the face of difficulties.

children.title: Examples of believers asking for assurance

seealsos.comment: The revelation of God's righteousness among his people results in true peace.

children.title: Such assurance proved false by conduct
assurance, basis of
children.comment: The assurance of believers is based upon the certain knowledge of God revealed in creation and his mighty acts in history, upon the certainty of his promises, the vindication and resurrection of Christ and the inward testimony and outward demonstration of the power of the Holy Spirit.

children.title: Such assurance proved false by conduct
athletics
children.comment: Sports engaged in by athletes. Scripture uses the image of running in a race to represent the Christian life. Believers should show similar perseverance as they press on to their heavenly reward.

cschildren.title: The Christian life is like running a race
Christians, like athletes, are to be single-minded
Christians, like athletes, are to persevere
The reward at the end of the race of life

seealsos.comment: The ``crown'' referred to is the garland or wreath awarded to the winner in athletics contests.

cschildren.title: The race is not necessarily won by the swiftest

children.title: certainty
children.comment: A sure knowledge or conviction that what is believed is true and trustworthy. Christian certainty does not arise from the credulity of the believer, but is based on the faithfulness and trustworthiness of God.

cschildren.title: Affirmations and statements of certainty
Certainty in God
Jesus Christ's certainty about his identity and mission
Certainty and the believer

children.title: Certainty about who Jesus Christ is
discipleship
children.comment: The process of becoming a committed follower of Jesus Christ, with all the spiritual discipline and benefits which this brings.

children.title: discipleship, nature of
children.comment: The state of following Jesus Christ, and serving and obeying him. The NT stresses the privileges, joys and cost of this calling.

children.title: Learning to do what is good
Jesus Christ calls people to be his disciples

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ calls James and John

children.title: Responding immediately to Jesus Christ's commands
Living for Jesus Christ and not for oneself
Total commitment is required of Jesus Christ's disciples
The purpose of discipleship is to become Christlike
discipleship, cost of
children.comment: The denial of self-interests and desires, and a total commitment to do the will of God, even to the point of death.

children.title: The cost of discipleship involves a denial of self-interests and desires
Self-denial means not living for oneself
The cost of discipleship is to be carefully considered
The cost of discipleship means total commitment to the will of God
The security of the world is to be resisted
Jesus Christ must have first priority
Jesus Christ must come before family ties
The cost of discipleship is constant
The cost of discipleship includes persecution
The cost of discipleship includes willingess to suffer and die for Jesus Christ's sake
discipleship, benefits of
children.comment: Joy, peace and happiness result from following Jesus Christ, together with the hope of being like him and with him in heaven. This is anticipated in the OT, which stresses the importance of obedience to the LORD.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ promises rest for the weary
the angels' greeting to the shepherds at the birth of Jesus Christ

Disciples are blessed by being united with Jesus Christ in the family of God
Disciples will be blessed with eternal life
Disciples have the hope of being like Jesus Christ and being with him in heaven

children.title: friendship, with God
children.comment: A relationship of love and faithfulness into which God calls all people through faith.

cschildren.title: Examples of friendship with God

primaryrefs.comment: ``the disciple whom Jesus loved'' is generally thought to be John.

cschildren.title: The ministry of Jesus Christ is an expression of friendship to sinners

children.title: In his death on the cross

cschildren.title: God's delight in friendship with those who he loves

God's invitation for people to know his friendship

primaryrefs.comment: Sharing a meal is a strong expression of friendship in Scripture.

children.title: guidance
children.comment: God has purposes and plans for his people, as individuals and communities. Believers and churches should seek his direction and counsel in discerning these purposes and plans in their lives.

children.title: guidance, God's promises of
children.comment: Scripture bears witness to God's promises of guidance for his people.

children.title: All God's intentions will be realised
God desires his purposes and plans to be fulfilled
Examples of God working out his purposes

secondaryrefs.comment: restoration of Israel after the exile

children.title: God promises to guide Israel and Judah
guidance, need for God's
children.comment: God's guidance is needed because people are naturally ignorant and rebellious and there are many who lead others astray.

children.title: The need to know and do the will of God
The concern of Jesus Christ to do the will of God
By themselves people are ignorant of the right way in life
Despite knowing God's will, sinners still rebel against him
The adverse consequences of false guidance and disobedience

children.comment: God's guidance is promised to those who genuinely desire it and seek it.

Guidance is given through the truth and counsel of God
Guidance is given to the humble and penitent
Guidance is given to those willing to obey God's will

The pillar of cloud and the pillar of fire

God's guidance likened to that of a shepherd

Examples of God's guidance being refused or disobeyed

children.comment: Scripture gives examples of God guiding his people through the example and witness of godly leaders and men and women of faith.

knowing God
children.comment: A faith-relationship and love-relationship with God involving mind, heart and will, and bringing experience of his presence and power. To know God is to worship him and be transformed by him. Human knowledge of God, which begins with knowledge about him, comes through God's self-revelation.

children.title: knowing God, nature of
children.comment: To know God is not merely to know things about him, such as his character, but also to experience his presence and power. To know God is to be transformed by him. Human knowledge of God is as a result of God's revelation of himself.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ praises the Father for the revelation the disciples receive

children.title: God gives knowledge of his reality through creation
God gives knowledge of his mercy and his will through Scripture, both law and gospel
God gives knowledge of himself through Jesus Christ
God gives knowledge of himself and his ways through the Spirit
God gives knowledge of his greatness and grace through experience of him, submission to him and in answer to prayer
To know Jesus Christ is to know God
To know God is to experience his salvation
knowing God, effects of
children.comment: Knowing God has a transforming effect on a person spiritually and morally and makes that person bold in actions for God. Not knowing God in the present will result in dissatisfaction and degeneration into wickedness and in the future will bring eternal alienation from him.

children.title: Spiritual transformation: from death to life
Moral transformation: from evil to good

secondaryrefs.comment: the parable of the lost son

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ's teaching on seeking first his kingdom

children.title: The peril of not knowing God
Lack of satisfaction and degeneration in the present

monotheism
children.comment: The central doctrine that there is one true God, who alone is the object of worship. There is none like the LORD; other gods and idols are nothing. Scripture also indicates that there is a network of relationships within the Godhead which is stated in terms of the doctrine of the Trinity.

cschildren.title: The doctrine of monotheism

children.title: There is none like the LORD
He alone is to be worshipped
He alone is to be served

primaryrefs.comment: Idols are nothing in themselves, but those worshipping them open themselves to demonic influence.

cschildren.title: Monotheism and plurality in the Godhead

seealsos.comment: The Spirit of God is seen as God's agent
The angel of the LORD is identified with, yet distinct from, God

children.title: prize
children.comment: Something of value given to those competing in a race, which the Christian life is likened to. Though believers must accept discipline and training, a prize is reserved for everyone who is committed to Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: A prize is reserved for all believers

primaryrefs.comment: The crown is the wreath given to the winner of a race.

cschildren.title: Requirements for winning the prize
Hindrances to winning the prize

children.title: religion
children.comment: A set of beliefs, a form of worship, ritual, prayer and a code of moral behaviour. True faith in God, moral standards and good works are important in relation to a biblical understanding of true religion, which is contrasted with the false religion of paganism.

cschildren.title: Belief

seealsos.comment: Belief by itself is insufficient for salvation.

cschildren.title: Worship
Ritual
Prayer
Code of behaviour

seealsos.comment: Religious people do not always see the inconsistencies in their behaviour

cschildren.title: True religious practice

children.title: renewal
children.comment: The regeneration or revitalisation that God brings to his people and creation, as part of the process of redemption.

children.title: renewal, of people of God
children.comment: The transformation by God of the lives of his people, whether corporately or individually, leading to the recovery of lost vitality and purity.

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ here prophesies the great act of renewal by God whereby the church rather than Israel becomes the people of God.

children.title: renewal, of natural order
children.comment: God's transformation of the natural order is part of his plan of redeeming the whole universe as well as humanity.

children.title: renewal, of people of God
children.comment: The transformation by God of the lives of his people, whether corporately or individually, leading to the recovery of lost vitality and purity.

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ here prophesies the great act of renewal by God whereby the church rather than Israel becomes the people of God.

children.title: renewal, of natural order
children.comment: God's transformation of the natural order is part of his plan of redeeming the whole universe as well as humanity.

children.title: revival
children.comment: The soveriegn activity of God whereby he renews his people individually and corporately in vigour, affecting both sincerity of belief and quality of behaviour.

children.title: revival, nature of
children.comment: Scripture indicates that a number of characteristics precede revival, including repentance, humility and obedience.

children.title: God's people long for renewal of their lives
God's people experience a new awareness of sin
God's people need to be humble
God's people are revived through God's initiative
People are zealous for God's work
revival, personal
children.comment: The bringing back of individuals to life or vigour both at the point of personal regeneration through the work of the Holy Spirit and at other times in believers' lives.

children.title: The Holy Spirit brings regeneration by giving spiritual life to those dead in sin
The believer must take responsibility for personal revival
God is active in bringing about personal revival
God's law may initiate personal revival

seealsos.comment: Peter had denied Jesus Christ seven weeks before.

children.title: revival, corporate
children.comment: The experience of God's people both in the OT and NT when prayer is answered and their growth and effectiveness are renewed.

children.title: The recurring pattern of apostasy and revival in the OT
God is petitioned to revive his people
God's people are urged to repent

seealsos.comment: Repentance should be evidenced by deeds.

children.title: God promises to revive his people
The nations are included in the promise of revival
The Holy Spirit is active in the revival of believers
The response of believers in revival

righteousness
children.comment: Scripture identifies a close link between righteousness and faith. Part of ``being in a right relationship with God'' is believing and trusting in him. The NT does not see faith simply in terms of moral righteousness, but also in terms of a living trusting relationship with God. Scripture affirms the righteousness of God and Jesus Christ in all their activity.

children.title: righteousness, as faith
children.comment: Full faith and trust make a person pleasing in the sight of God.

children.title: Human righteousness compared with God's righteousness
Human beings cannot by themselves achieve righteousness in the sight of God
True righteousness is the result of the action of God
Righteousness and faith in Jesus Christ
It is God-given and not the result of human effort

primaryrefs.comment: Paul is contrasting this righteousness with his own previous efforts.

seealsos.comment: It is apparent that faith is not regarded as another kind of ``work'' which earns salvation

children.title: Faith is centred on Jesus Christ and what he has accomplished

primaryrefs.comment: ``justified'' means ``declared righteous'' in a legal sense.

children.title: Saving faith is not mere belief, but acting on the basis of that belief
righteousness, of believers
children.comment: A sincere desire to please God by keeping his law is both commanded and approved by him. However, human fallibility means that true righteousness must be the product of the Holy Spirit's work in the believer.

children.title: Righteousness includes keeping the laws of God
God requires righteousness of his people
God loves those who are righteous
The righteous receive blessing from God
The righteous may suffer for their faith
righteousness, as faith
children.comment: Full faith and trust make a person pleasing in the sight of God.

children.title: Human righteousness compared with God's righteousness

seeking God
children.comment: God's desire is that all people should seek after him and find him. Those who seek God with all their heart are rewarded, but those who fail to seek him do so to their eternal loss.

cschildren.title: God's heart is for people to seek him

children.title: God wants people to seek him
God calls people to seek him
God promises that people will seek him
God promises to be found by those who seek him
God's opportunity for seeking him is now and is restricted to this life

cschildren.title: Seeking God is an issue of the heart

children.title: Seeking God begins in the heart
Wholeheartedness in seeking God is required

cschildren.title: Seeking God and his kingdom is the priority of life

children.title: It leads to understanding and wisdom

cschildren.title: Hindrances to seeking God
Seeking God through occult practices is forbidden

children.title: spiritual vitality
children.comment: The quality of possessing a living faith, which is commended by Scripture.

cschildren.title: Spiritual vitality commended
The means of developing spiritual vitality

children.title: Being filled with the Holy Spirit

cschildren.title: Obstacles to spiritual vitality

children.title: A failure to progress beyond basic teachings

cschildren.title: Examples of individuals with spiritual vitality
The consequences of spiritual vitality

children.title: spirituality
children.comment: The quality of life generated and nourished by the Spirit of God, in which believers experience the power and presence of God in their lives. True spirituality comes from living under the control of the Holy Spirit and is evidenced by the fruit of the Spirit, spiritual maturity and growth in holiness.

cschildren.title: The foundations of spirituality
The nature of spirituality

children.title: Intimacy with God through the Spirit

cschildren.title: Evidence of spirituality
Aids to spirituality
Examples of spirituality

children.title: theology
children.comment: The study of God, as he has revealed himself in Jesus Christ and in Scripture.

cschildren.title: Theology is based on God's self-revelation
The benefits of theology

children.title: A concern for right teaching in the church
An inspiration to meditation and praise
A life of obedience and holiness
way, the
children.comment: A term used metaphorically to refer both to the Christian faith (especially in Acts) and to Jesus Christ himself (especially in John's Gospel). Faith in Jesus Christ is the only way of salvation for sinful human beings. The term is often used with other expressions in Scripture to describe aspects of the life of the believer.

cschildren.title: The Way refers to the Christian faith
The way refers to Jesus Christ himself
Faith in Jesus Christ is the only way of salvation for sinful human beings
Way used with other terms to describe the life of faith
